DOC.HEAD: Tougher Van Door Standards Proposed
Eds: Subs graf 2, The proposals, to include time element
DOC.TEXT: The Transportation Department is proposing tougher standards for door strength in minivans, small buses and other light-weight vehicles exempt from some automobile standards. The proposals announced Wednesday would subject all trucks, buses and multipurpose vehicles with a gross weight rate of 10,000 pounds or less to the same door-strength crash tests as passenger cars. ``More and more of these vehicles are being used on the nation's highways, and we believe they should have a higher level of protection in side-impact crashes,'' said Jerry Ralph Curry, head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Car doors must be built to resist the crushing force of a steel cylinder in laboratory tests. The new rule to be effective with 1993 model trucks would go into effect after a 60-day period for comment. Curry noted that sales of light trucks, mostly minivans, have increased during the 1980s and now total 5 million a year. This has resulted in increased injuries and deaths to occupants of such vehicles, he said. The government's move drew praise from Sen. Jack Danforth, R-Mo., principal sponsor of a bill to require stronger side impact protection for small trucks, minivans and four-wheel drive vehicles. The bill cleared the Senate in August and is pending in the House. ``I hope for quick department action to finalize this proposal and to build upon it,'' Danforth said. ``Most families do not realize that minivans and other light trucks are not as safe as passenger cars.''
